data.title: 3 Best Low P/E Stocks Poised for 30%+ Gains in 2026
data.description:
Using the TipRanks Stock Screener Tool, we identified three companies that have low Price-to-Earnings (P/E) ratios and hold a “Strong Buy” consensus rating. Each stock also presents an impressive >60% upside potential within the next year, making them compelling investment choices.

Claim 50% Off TipRanks Premium

  • Unlock hedge fund-level data and powerful investing tools for smarter, sharper decisions
  • Stay ahead of the market with the latest news and analysis and maximize your portfolio's potential

Why Low P/E Stocks?

Low P/E stocks trade at a discount to their earnings, letting you buy more profit per dollar invested. This inherent margin of safety buffers against market dips and losses. While some chase high P/E names for rapid growth, history shows low P/E picks often yield better long-term returns with lower risk. They also tend to offer generous dividends, hail from established companies with steady growth, and exhibit less volatility.

Block (XYZ)

  • P/E Ratio: 10.4x (77% below sector median of 32x)
  • Average Block Price Target: $86.74 (36.4% upside)

Block, formerly known as Square, is a fintech firm that offers payments, lending, and related services to businesses, merchants, and individuals through its Square and Cash Apps. Block’s fourth-quarter adjusted earnings per share came in at $0.65, while gross profit rose to $2.87 billion. This was due to the strong growth of the Cash App ecosystem, which increased by 33% year-over-year. Block also announced plans to cut roughly 40% of its workforce to improve efficiency.

JD.com (JD)

  • P/E Ratio: 9.3x (77% below sector median of 32x)
  • Average JD.com Price Target: $37.97 (43% upside)

JD.com is a leading Chinese e-commerce and logistics company, offering online retail, marketplace services, and fast delivery across China. JD also pays handsome dividends of $0.98 per share annually, reflecting an attractive yield of 3.37%. JD presents a compelling investment case due to its undervalued stock, robust logistics moat, and shareholder returns amid steady growth.

Rithm Capital (RITM)

  • P/E Ratio: 9.8x (77% below sector median of 32x)
  • Average Rithm Capital Price Target: $14.50 (43.7% upside)

Rithm Capital offers a diversified business model with a focus on REITs and as a global asset manager in areas such as credit and financial services. The company also offers an above-industry-average dividend yield of 8.95%, making it an attractive dividend stock. RITM’s Q4 2025 results beat estimates with EPS of $0.74 (vs. $0.55 expected) and revenue of $1.29 billion (vs. $1.24 billion), delivering 15.55% net margins and 19.74% return on equity.
data.author: Sheryl Sheth

data.title: Costco Stock (COST) Is Still a Great Buy after Valuation Reset
data.description:
Costco (COST) has just undergone a massive valuation reset, recording its largest drawdown (17.4%) since mid-2022 at the very end of last year. The key difference this time, however, is that the selloff was largely uncorrelated with the broader market (S&P 500 (SPY)), suggesting that the move was thesis-specific rather than macro-driven.

data.title: Petrobras Finds Support in Oil and FX, but the Dividend Story Is Shifting
data.description:
Petróleo Brasileiro S.A. (PBR), better known as Petrobras, has been among the highest dividend yielders in the global energy sector in recent years. Petrobras explores for, produces, and sells oil and gas in Brazil and internationally. Despite its impressive income profile, its stock remained under pressure for much of the past two years. Early 2026 has marked a shift, with the ADR rebounding nearly 40% over the last three months amid firmer Brent oil prices and FX tailwinds.

data.title: Cash Flow Mining Giant VALE Braces For Brutal Commodity Cycle
data.description:
The global commodities market is changing in ways that would have seemed unlikely only a few years ago. As economies push toward electrification while still grappling with persistent supply constraints, Brazilian mining giant Vale S.A. (VALE) has emerged as a compelling long-term play, despite the inherent cyclicality of the business. Between a favorable geopolitical backdrop and a robust pricing environment for industrial metals, the stars are aligning for this South American titan, and this could be the case for a while. Accordingly, I am bullish on the stock.

data.title: 3 iShares China ETFs: Analysts See 20%+ Upside Amid Risks
data.description:
Geopolitical tensions and evolving global trade dynamics are encouraging investors to spread risk across regions. We used the TipRanks Compare ETFs Tool to determine three China-focused ETFs – FXI, ISVBF, and MCHI that are expected to generate more than 20% gains over the next twelve months. These ETFs reveal varied approaches to capturing China’s expansion despite regulatory shifts, policy adjustments, and market swings. Let’s briefly understand them.

  • Unlock hedge fund-level data and powerful investing tools for smarter, sharper decisions

iShares China Large-Cap ETF (FXI)

The iShares China Large-Cap ETF focuses on large companies, giving you a portfolio of high-cap stocks that lead the Chinese market. It covers many sectors including finance, technology, telecoms, and consumer goods. It tracks the FTSE China 50 Net Tax USD Index.

FXI also offers an above-industry-average dividend yield of 2.38%, with semi-annual payouts of $0.416 per share. FXI has one of the highest expense ratios of 0.74%, and an AUM of $6.41 billion.

According to TipRanks’ unique ETF analyst consensus, determined based on a weighted average of analyst ratings on its holdings, FXI is a Strong Buy. The Street’s average price target of $48.81 implies an upside of 25.8%.

data.description:

Despite Meta’s stock being down 2.5% so far this year, investors will still be watching closely for their dividend checks. data.title: Coca-Cola (KO) Raises Its Divided for a 64th Consecutive Year
data.description:
Coca-Cola Co. (KO) has raised its quarterly dividend for the 64th consecutive year.

President's Day Sale - 70% Off

  • Unlock hedge fund-level data and powerful investing tools for smarter, sharper decisions
  • Stay ahead of the market with the latest news and analysis and maximize your portfolio's potential

The Atlanta, Georgia-based beverage giant has increased its quarterly dividend payment by 4% to $0.53 per share. It’s the 64 consecutive years that the company has increased its distribution to shareholders, making the stock a Dividend King.

The title Dividend King is reserved for company’s that have increased their dividend for 50 years or more. In Coke’s case, the new dividend will be payable on April 1 of this year to stockholders of record as of March 13, with an ex-dividend date of March 12.

Coca-Cola’s Shareholder Returns

The latest increase gives KO stock an annual dividend of $2.12 per share, and an annualized yield of 2.7%. In addition to the dividend, Coca-Cola also returns value to shareholders through periodic stock buybacks. In November 2025, the company repurchased $2.4 billion of its own stock from a subsidiary.

Management at Coca-Cola have long prioritized the company’s dividend, as have shareholders of the company. Arguably the most famous of Coke’s shareholders is legendary investor Warren Buffett, who has held the same 400 million shares of KO stock since 1994. With the new distribution, Buffett stands to earn $848 million a year in dividends from his Coca-Cola holding.

Is KO Stock a Buy?

Coca-Cola stock has a consensus Strong Buy rating among 15 Wall Street analysts. That rating is based on 14 Buy and one Hold recommendations issued in the last three months. The average KO price target of $84.93 implies 7.71% upside from current levels.
data.author: Joel Baglole

data.title: Melius Research Turns Bullish on Chevron (CVX) Stock. Here’s Why
data.description:
Melius Research upgraded Chevron (CVX) stock to Buy from Hold with a price target of $205, saying “Chevron’s strategy couldn’t be clearer: value over volume.” The analyst turned bullish on the oil and gas giant, citing momentum in its exploration activity and the underappreciated upside presented by the opportunity in Venezuela.

President's Day Sale - 70% Off

  • Unlock hedge fund-level data and powerful investing tools for smarter, sharper decisions
  • Stay ahead of the market with the latest news and analysis and maximize your portfolio's potential

Melius Analyst Upgrades CVX Stock to Buy

Melius analyst James West expects Chevron to benefit from increased exploration spending and new talent from the Hess acquisition. The analyst highlighted that the company has increased its acreage position by more than 50%, with the addition of ten new basin positions over the past two years. West also noted new opportunities in Libya and Iraq.

He added that Chevron anticipates drilling at least 10 to 15 exploration wells, with the Gulf of America, Libya, Namibia, Nigeria, Angola, Suriname, Brazil, and Guyana presenting attractive areas for exploration. West also highlighted that Chevron is in the best position to capture upside potential in Venezuela.

The analyst is also impressed by the leadership of CEO Mike Wirth, who he believes “ushered in an era of disciplined M&A, cash generation, and strategic growth.”

Overall, West is optimistic about Chevron based on its differentiated investment profile that is highlighted by:

  • a focus on shareholder returns via dividends and buybacks
  • an increase in exploration activity focused on high-impact frontier areas
  • a shift to cash harvesting in the Permian basin rather than growth
  • upside potential in Venezuela.

Is CVX Stock a Buy, Sell, or Hold?

Wall Street has a Moderate Buy consensus rating on Chervon stock based on 15 Buys and six Holds. The average CVX stock price target of $186.50 indicates 3.1% upside potential from current levels. Chevron stock has risen about 19% so far in 2026. CVX stock offers a dividend yield of 4.5%.
data.author: Sirisha Bhogaraju

data.title: NextEra Energy (NEE) Raises Dividend by 10%
data.description:
NextEra Energy (NEE) has raised its quarterly dividend payment by 10%.

Valentine's Day Sale - 70% Off

  • Unlock hedge fund-level data and powerful investing tools for smarter, sharper decisions
  • Stay ahead of the market with the latest news and analysis and maximize your portfolio's potential

The largest U.S. electric utility said that, going forward, it will pay a distribution to stockholders of $0.6232 per share, or $2.49 a year. That’s up 10% from the previous quarterly dividend payout of $0.57. The annual yield on the new dividend is 2.60%.

NextEra Energy said that the new dividend will be payable on March 16 of this year to stockholders of record as of Feb. 27, with an ex-dividend date of Feb. 26. The utility company is considered a “Dividend Aristocrat,” having increased its distribution to shareholders every year since 1995.

NextEra’s Dividend Plans

In addition to the new 10% hike in its quarterly dividend, NextEra Energy’s management team also said that it plans to further increase the company’s dividend by 6% in both 2027 and 2028. The increased distributions align with NextEra’s commitment to returning value to shareholders.

The dividend increases are being announced about two weeks after NextEra Energy reported its latest financial results. The company managed to report earnings and revenue that slightly beat Wall Street forecasts. NEE stock has risen 35% in the last 12 months.

Is NEE Stock a Buy?

NextEra Energy’s stock has a consensus Moderate Buy rating among 15 Wall Street analysts. That rating is based on 10 Buy and five Hold recommendations issued in the last three months. The average NEE price target of $94.07 implies 0.42% downside from current levels.
data.author: Joel Baglole

data.title: The 3 Tech Dividend Stocks Bridging the Income Gap: META, ORCL, and TXN
data.description:
Technology stocks are known for innovation and rapid growth — but reliable income has rarely been part of the package. That dynamic is beginning to change. A growing number of tech companies are embracing cash dividends, following the example of legacy players like Texas Instruments (TXN), which has rewarded shareholders with payouts since before the moon landing.

Valentine's Day Sale - 70% Off

  • Unlock hedge fund-level data and powerful investing tools for smarter, sharper decisions
  • Stay ahead of the market with the latest news and analysis and maximize your portfolio's potential

Once focused almost exclusively on reinvesting cash flow into expansion, many technology leaders are now adopting a two-track strategy: pursuing growth while also returning capital directly to investors. By tapping strong balance sheets and steady free cash flow, they’re transforming the sector into a more attractive option for income-seeking portfolios.

Companies such as Oracle (ORCL), Meta Platforms (META), and Texas Instruments are at the forefront of this transformation, helping reshape the technology sector into one that not only pursues growth but also consistently rewards shareholders with income. By combining strong cash generation with disciplined capital returns, these firms are closing the income gap in tech and enhancing overall return potential for long-term investors.
data.author: Gerelyn Terzo

data.title: BP Stock Plunges as British Energy Giant Suspends Buybacks amid Weak Oil Prices
data.description:
British energy giant BP (BP) has suspended share buybacks as part of its efforts to allocate surplus cash to “strengthen the balance sheet.” BP’s U.S.-listed shares plunged 6% in pre-market trading, while the London-listed shares (GB:BP) were down more than 4% at the time of writing. Oil companies have been under pressure due to lower crude prices amid oversupply. BP made the announcement alongside its fourth-quarter and full-year results for 2025. The company reported an underlying replacement cost profit (a metric similar to net profit) of $1.54 billion for Q4 2025, in line with analysts’ consensus estimate.

Valentine's Day Sale - 70% Off

  • Unlock hedge fund-level data and powerful investing tools for smarter, sharper decisions
  • Stay ahead of the market with the latest news and analysis and maximize your portfolio's potential

However, the Q4 underlying replacement cost profit reflected a decline from $2.21 billion in the third quarter of 2025 due to lower upstream realizations, unfavorable upstream production mix, and lower refinery throughputs. The bottom line was also impacted by the temporary outage at the Whiting refinery and seasonally lower customer volumes.

BP and Rivals Face Challenges Due to Weakness in Oil Prices

Last week, BP’s rivals Shell (SHEL) and Equinor (EQNR) posted dismal quarterly earnings, citing lower crude prices, among other reasons. Shell announced a buyback plan of $3.5 billion, marking the 17th consecutive quarter with $3 billion or more in share repurchases. However, Equinor said that it would slash its share buybacks to $1.5 billion in 2026 from $5 billion last year. Equinor is also reducing its spending on renewables and low-emission energy initiatives.

Meanwhile, BP is streamlining its business to mitigate the impact of ongoing challenges and improve its position following years of underperformance compared to peers. Interim CEO Carol Howle highlighted that the company has made progress on its four primary goals: increasing cash flows, enhancing returns, reducing costs, and strengthening the balance sheet. Howle added that the company is aware of the “urgency to deliver.” It is worth noting that Woodside Energy (WDS) head Meg O’Neill will be assuming the role of BP’s CEO effective April 1, 2026, succeeding Murray Auchincloss, who stepped down in late 2025.

Meanwhile, BP has increased its structural cost-reduction target to the range of $5.5 billion to $6.5 billion by the end of 2027, up from the previous target of up to $5 billion.

Is BP Stock a Buy, Sell, or Hold?

Given the ongoing challenges, Wall Street has a Hold consensus rating on BP stock based on five Holds, three Buys, and one Sell recommendation. The average BP stock price target of $40.31 indicates about 3% upside potential.

These ratings/price targets are expected to be revised as analysts react to Q4 results and outlook.
data.author: Sirisha Bhogaraju

data.title: PepsiCo (PEP) Defies Risk-Off Mood as Investors Question Bullish Stock Market
data.description:
PepsiCo (PEP) entered 2026 with a fourth-quarter report that, at first glance, painted a conflicted picture. At the operating level, organic growth remained flat, and volumes in Foods North America (PFNA) were under pressure with pricing power continuing to disappear—not the backdrop for a traditional upside case. But despite these events, PepsiCo still managed (somewhat miraculously) to deliver a double-digit increase in operating profit, very robust cash flows, and reaffirm respectable full-year guidance.

data.title: Coca-Cola Earnings Tomorrow – Should You Buy KO Stock Ahead of Q4?
data.description:
Coca-Cola (KO) is set to release its fourth-quarter fiscal 2025 results before the market opens tomorrow, February 10. Analysts expect modest sales and earnings growth from the beverage giant. KO stock hit a new 52-week high of $79.20 on February 6, and has surged more than 12% over the past month, fueled by steady demand and strong pricing power.

Valentine's Day Sale - 70% Off

  • Unlock hedge fund-level data and powerful investing tools for smarter, sharper decisions
  • Stay ahead of the market with the latest news and analysis and maximize your portfolio's potential

Investors will watch for clues on risks like a strong dollar, pressure on low-income consumers, shifting beverage preferences, and the upcoming CEO transition. On February 6, Coca-Cola announced that it is discontinuing its frozen products category in North America “in response to shifting consumer preferences” and will continue focusing on the juice category. Investors will also see if the Dividend King will raise its annual dividend this year. Currently, KO pays a regular dividend of $0.51 per share, reflecting 2.92% yield.

The company also faces stiff competition from Pepsi (PEP), which posted robust Q4 results recently. Henrique Braun, Coca-Cola’s current Executive VP and COO, will replace James Quincey as CEO on March 31, 2026.

Expectations from Coca-Cola

The Street expects Coca-Cola to post adjusted earnings per share (EPS) of $0.57, up from $0.55 a year ago. Sales are forecast to rise 4.4% year-over-year to $12.05 billion. Notably, Coca-Cola has beaten earnings expectations for eight straight quarters.

Meanwhile, options traders expect about a 2.99% move in either direction for KO stock in reaction to Q4FY25 results. This implied move is slightly higher than Coca-Cola stock’s average post-earnings move (in absolute terms) of 2.24% over the past four quarters.
data.author: Sheryl Sheth
